title: About Me
text: <image src=“./profile_pic.jpeg”, alt=“headshot”, width=“200”>

title: About Me
text:
Background
Hello! I am a senior at Brigham Young University in Utah, but am originally from Montana. I enjoy living in a state where the outdoors is always just a few minutes away, whether its skiing, hiking, or fishing, I love it all. I have a wide range of interests in the field of data science, mainly related to personal experiences and hobbies. I am Hispanic as well as a first-generation American and student. This combined with pre-medical coursework in high school contributes to my interest in immigrant healthcare statistics. I also grew up watching baseball as a family activity, so sports analytics is something that I am passionate about.

title: About Me
text:
Education

Statistics (data science emphasis)- Brigham Young University, Expected Graduation Date: April, 2026
Information Systems - Minor
Relevant Coursework: Statistics, Data Analysis, Python and Javascript programming

title: About Me
text:
Experience

Orem Rehab and Skilled Nursing - I spent three years working at a skilled nursing facility, directly working with patients and assisting in activities of daily life. Part of my duties entailed communicating with Spanish speaking patients and recording information relevant to their conditions. I feel that this unique connection to and understanding of the healthcare field, specifically regarding the immigrant population, allows me to more effectively analyze immigrant healthcare statistics.

title: About Me
text:
Skills & Interests

Technical Skills

Programming: Python, JavaScript, React
Data Analysis: Pandas, NumPy
Visualization: Matplotlib, Seaborn
Machine Learning: Scikit-learn
Tools: Jupyter Notebooks, Git/GitHub



Areas of Interest

Immigrant healthcare analytics
MLB (baseball) statistics

title: About Me
text:
Goals
In the short term, I hope to become more proficient with the data analysis process as a whole, going from choosing a dataset, cleaning it, visualizing it, and drawing conclusions. This is something that will come with practice and that I hope to highlight through my posts on this site. In the long term, I hope to be working in one of my areas of interest, either working for the government performing data analysis and inference based on immigrant healthcare data to better serve that population, or working with the MLB to identify variables of interest based on current season data.

title: About Me
text:
Get to Know Me
I love to work with kids, in the past I have worked as a substitute teacher and volunteered my time at local elementary schools. I also love to travel, although I do not frequently have the opportunity to due to the costs associated with being a student. I have been able to combine these passions in a meaningful way by volunteering in Mexico, the Dominican Republic, and Taiwan

title: Strikeouts Over Time: Plotting Pitcher Trends
text:
Baseball has a stat for everything, from the well known “batting average” to more obscure statistics such as “OPS”, “fWAR”, and “ERA+”. When all these different statistics are thrown together in a table, it can be hard to understand what exactly the jumble of numbers mean. In this tutorial, I will go through the process of turning raw data from a .csv file into interpretable charts where relationships between parameters of interest can be analyzed.
By the end, you’ll be able to:

Load a CSV of pitcher stats into pandas

Filter the data to a single pitcher

Summarize strikeouts by year

Plot a simple, readable line chart in matplotlib

I will go through this process using recently retired Dodgers pitcher Clayton Kershaw, but you can pick any pitcher you’d like for this tutorial!



The MLB makes a lot of their data avaliable through online tools like MLB Baseball Savant (Statcast search). For this tutorial I would recommend using this same site, although there are others, such as BaseballReference.com and Sportsradar.com. To start out this project, we will:

Use a web interface (like Statcast search or another MLB stats page).

Filter for pitchers, under “included stats” check strikeouts and export the results as a CSV file.

Save it as something like pitcher_stats.csv in the same folder as your notebook/script.

The CSV will have many columns, but should at least include these three columns:

player_name – pitcher’s name

year – year of the season (e.g., 2019, 2020, …)

so – strikeouts


import pandas as pd

# Read in your downloaded MLB pitcher stats
df = pd.read_csv("../pitcher_stats.csv")

# Take a quick look at the columns and first few rows
#print(df.columns) (Uncomment this line to check the column names!)
df.head()

player_id
player_name
year
total_pitches
pitch_percent
ba
iso
babip
slg
...

wobadiff
swing_miss_percent

attack_angle
attack_direction
swing_path_tilt
rate_ideal_attack_angle
intercept_ball_minus_batter_pos_x_inches
intercept_ball_minus_batter_pos_y_inches

5 rows × 77 columns






You’ll want to pick your pitcher and filter the dataset to only include that pitcher. Here you’ll also want to sort the values by season.

#Pick your pitcher
pitcher_name = "Kershaw, Clayton"

#Filter the dataset
pitcher_df = df.query("player_name == @pitcher_name").copy()

# Make sure season is sorted numerically
pitcher_df["year"] = pitcher_df["year"].astype(int)
pitcher_df = pitcher_df.sort_values("year")




Now that the dataset looks how we want it to, we can start visualizing it on a plot. We will use the matplotlib library to do this.

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (8, 5))

#Here we create the plot by assigning season to the x-axis and strikeouts to the y-axis.
ax.plot(
  pitcher_df["year"],
  pitcher_df["so"],
  marker = "o",
  linestyle = "-"
)

#It's important to set labels for our plot as many times variable names are not easily recognizable.
ax.set_xticks(pitcher_df["year"])
ax.set_title(f"Strikeouts per Season for {pitcher_name}")
ax.set_xlabel("Season")
ax.set_ylabel("Total Strikeouts")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()











Depending on which pitcher you have chosen, you might have different things stick out to you. For example:

Is there a season where the strikeout count jumps up or falls sharply?
Is your pitcher consistent or did they just have one breakout season?
Is your pitcher trending up or down over time?

After seeing the trends in your data, you can explore even further. Another statistic that is frequently used is K/9, which refers to the number of strikeouts per 9 innings. This can be more accurate to a pitchers actual ability as it can account for time spent injured or not playing as a starter. By modifying the code above, it can be a simple change to create a new column with values obtained by dividing the strikeouts by the innings pitched, then multiplying by 9.



Now that you’ve seen me go through this process for Clayton Kershaw, you can take this code and make your own plot using any pitcher and any statistic. This code can be copied and pasted directly into a python script and run to create your own custom stat-over-time plot.
When you’re finished, you should have a working python script, a simple, clean line plot using real MLB data, and a starting point for deeper sports analytics projects. The basic flow taught here, load in data -> filter -> group by desired stat -> plot data, can be used as a starting point for almost any dataset to visualize data. Good luck!

title: Welcome to My Data Science Portfolio
text:
Welcome to my data science portfolio! This is where I will post interesting projects that I am currently or have previously worked on. You will be able to see some highlights from the data analysis I have done both as part of class projects and from personal projects. I love sports analytics, so the majority of my projects will probably be baseball or football related. I will be updating this page regularly as I continue to refine my data science related skills, so maek sure to check in regularly to see what I’m working on. Check out the about me page to get to know me and see more of my background.


This portfolio shows my work learning data science. Each project includes:

My code with documentation
Visualizations I created
What I learned and discovered

I built this site using Quarto and host it on GitHub Pages.




Programming: Python, Pandas for data analysis
Visualization: Creating charts with Matplotlib and Seaborn
Data Collection: Getting data from files, websites, and APIs
Analysis: Finding patterns and answering questions with data







Learn how I explore datasets to find interesting patterns and answer questions.



See how I gather data from different sources and prepare it for analysis.



See how I tackle a data science project beginning to end.



Thanks for visiting! Feel free to explore my projects and see what I’m learning.
